item.title: Investigators Say Mexico Has Thwarted Efforts to Solve Students’ Disappearance
item.media:description: Family and friends of the missing students blocked traffic near the Interior Ministry in Mexico City on April 15 in a protest to demand justice.
item.description: International experts brought to Mexico to investigate the disappearance of 43 students say they have faced sustained harassment and stonewalling.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Brazil’s Dilma Rousseff, at U.N. Climate Ceremony, Assails ‘Coup Mongers’
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil addressed the United Nations opening ceremony in New York on Friday to mark the passage of the landmark agreement on climate change.
item.description: Ms. Rousseff used the international platform to assert that the campaign to oust her from office is little more than a coup d’état.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Women Who Fled Boko Haram Tell of Devastation and, Rarely, Hope
item.media:description: Refugees at the camp in Yola, Nigeria, during a visit by Samantha Power, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, on Friday.
item.description: In a Nigerian refugee camp visited by Samantha Power, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, women and girls bear the scars of life in the militants’ path.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Deal Is Reached to Return the Opposition Leader Riek Machar to South Sudan
item.description: The government of Salva Kiir said it was prepared to take a step toward ending a civil war that has left tens of thousands of people dead and two million displaced.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Russian Military Buildup Near Aleppo, Syria, Threatens Truce, Kerry Warns
item.media:description: Volunteers evacuated airstrike victims in Aleppo, Syria, on Friday. Russian support has aided the government’s advance on the city.
item.description: The American secretary of state said Russia had moved heavy artillery into position outside the city in northern Syria.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Obama Warns Britain on Trade if It Leaves European Union
item.description: The president, speaking alongside Prime Minister David Cameron, said a Britain outside the bloc would move to the “back of the queue” for a trade deal with the United States.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Portugal Clears the Way for Extradition of Ex-C.I.A. Agent to Italy
item.media:description: The former C.I.A. agent Sabrina De Sousa at her home in Washington in 2013.
item.media:credit: Barbara L. Salisbury/McClatchy Company and Tribune Company, via Getty Images
item.description: The former agent, who lives in Portugal, will be handed over to Italy, where she was convicted of taking part in the 2003 abduction of an Egyptian cleric.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Russia’s New Human Rights Ombudsman Is Former Police General
item.description: The election of Tatyana N. Moskalkova, who was trained in Soviet times, drew criticism from human rights advocates.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: U.N. Rights Chief Warns Against Thai Military’s Quest for More Authority
item.media:description: Thai military officers secured an area of Bangkok in 2014. Critics say the military junta is becoming increasingly authoritarian.
item.description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein urged the country’s junta to suspend “dangerous” powers they are set to acquire under a draft constitution.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Fighting to Save Forests in Cambodia, an Activist Puts Himself at Risk
item.media:description: Ouch Leng, an environmental activist, at home with his family on the outskirts of Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Mr. Leng’s supporters say he has an unusually broad range of assets, including a national network of contacts.
item.media:credit: Luc Forsyth for The New York Times
item.description: Supporters of Ouch Leng, who goes undercover to document illegal logging, fear that his growing prominence will make him a target of violence.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sinosphere: China to Develop Floating Nuclear Power Plants
item.description: A fleet of vessels would provide electricity to remote locations, including disputed islands in the South China Sea, the state news media said.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Honduran Ex-Police Chief Says Government Faked Documents in Assassination Case
item.media:description: Ramón Sabillón Pineda, a police general, says corruption in Honduras is even larger than suggested in a set of leaked papers.
item.description: Ramón Sabillón Pineda, a police general, says that files implicating officers in the killing of two antidrug officials are part of a “crude setup.”
item.dc:creator: ALBERTO ARCE

item.title: As Holocaust Becomes More Distant, Survivors’ Needs Intensify
item.media:description: Holocaust survivors attended a ceremony at the Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp in Oswiecim, Poland, in January.
item.description: As the survivors of Nazi brutality become ever older, an effort to have Germany spend more on in-home care for them has taken on a new urgency.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: ISIS Ex-Hostages Identify Brussels Suicide Bomber as Captor
item.media:description: Najim Laachraoui
item.description: A lawyer for Nicolas Hénin and Pierre Torres, two French journalists detained by the group in Syria, said the former captives had recognized Najim Laachraoui.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Boris Johnson’s Essay on Obama and Churchill Touches Nerve Online
item.description: It did not attack the president directly, but suggested that the U.S. would not surrender its sovereignty as, the London mayor argued, Britain had done with the European Union.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Printers at German Universities Mysteriously Churn Out Anti-Semitic Fliers
item.description: Institutions in Hamburg, Lüneburg and Tübingen said that their networks may have been hacked, and that many of the leaflets were printed on the anniversary of Hitler’s birth.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Moroccan Was Planning a Terrorist Attack in Spain, Judge Finds
item.media:description: Mohamed Harrak was questioned on Thursday by a judge in Madrid.
item.description: The man, Mohamed Harrak, 26, was arrested on the island of Majorca on Tuesday, after two months of surveillance.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Fraud Suspects From Taiwan Have Confessed, Chinese State Media Reports
item.description: The suspects, accused of cheating mainland Chinese by telephone from a base in Kenya, were deported to China this month, stirring concern in Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: London Becomes a Leading Destination for French Jews After Attacks
item.media:description: The Anshei Shalom Synagogue in St. John’s Wood, a Sephardic synagogue, opened 13 years ago with very few French Jews. Today, 70 percent of the 160-member congregation is French.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: As France grapples with radical Islam and a rise in anti-Semitic acts, a growing number of Jews are choosing to settle in the British capital.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Liao Yiwu on ‘Love in the Time of Mao’
item.media:description: The Chinese writer Liao Yiwu, in Brussels in 2013.
item.media:credit: Colin Delfosse for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Liao discusses his family’s experiences under Mao Zedong and how his novel, to be published later this year in Chinese and English, came about.
item.dc:creator: LUO SILING
item.category: Love in the Time of Mao (Book)

item.title: In Spain, Catching Up With Cervantes
item.media:description: Members of Factoria Teatro performing parts of Cervantes’s “The Spanish-English Lady” on the Madrid subway this month.
item.description: State-sponsored events to honor the writer on the 400th anniversary of his death fall short, critics say.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Vancouver Prescriptions for Addicts Gain Attention as Heroin and Opioid Use Rises
item.media:description: Dave Napio, 55, at a single-room occupancy hotel after receiving one of his three daily drug doses at the Crosstown Clinic in Vancouver, British Columbia.
item.description: Treatment known as heroin maintenance has helped keep users out of jail and away from emergency rooms, but concerns about drug abuse stymie such programs in the United States.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Frederick Mayer, Jew Who Spied on Nazis After Fleeing Germany, Dies at 94
item.media:description: Frederick Mayer, right, with Franz Weber, left, and Hans Wijnberg, in an undated photograph, took part in the Greenup operation, parachuting into Austria in 1945 to spy on Nazi troop activity.
item.description: Seven years after leaving Germany with his family, Mr. Mayer parachuted into Austria as an American spy and helped to hasten the Nazi surrender.
item.dc:creator: ERIC LICHTBLAU

item.title: U.N. Urges U.S. and Russia to Act Quickly to Save Syria Peace Talks
item.media:description: Residents of Hayy Aqyul, a rebel-held neighborhood of Aleppo, Syria, tried on Friday to escape what observers said were government airstrikes.
item.description: The senior envoy said the fragile truce announced in February between the government and opposition groups could be “in great trouble.”
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Despite Campaign Vow, Obama Declines to Call Massacre of Armenians ‘Genocide’
item.description: Critics say Mr. Obama, in an effort to curry favor with Turkey, has repeatedly ignored a campaign pledge he made in 2008.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Mali Arrests Suspect in Hotel and Restaurant Attacks
item.description: The man, Fawaz Ould Ahmed, is suspected of being part of a group linked to Al Qaeda that struck civilians at locations frequented by Westerners.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb

item.title: Opinion: Frozen Life in Wartime Syria
item.media:description: An elementary school in Aleppo, Syria, damaged in fighting. Five years of civil war has put Syrians’ lives on hold.
item.description: What does survival look like for the million people behind siege lines with no sugar, no power and little hope?
item.dc:creator: JANINE DI GIOVANNI
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In Ecuador, Political Aftershocks
item.media:description: Rescue workers search for survivors in Portoviejo, Ecuador.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: With the country reeling from a devastating earthquake, the most effective relief efforts have come from citizens, not the government.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN PALLARES

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Better the Saudis We Know
item.media:description: President Obama with Saudi Foreign Minister Adel Al-Jubeir on Thursday.
item.description: Despite tensions, the U.S. cannot afford to cut adrift a key regional ally.
item.dc:creator: BERNARD HAYKEL and STEFFEN HERTOG

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: Dispatch from Dakar: ‘Where Is This Flight Going?’ and Other Basic Questions About African Travel
item.media:description: A moldy airplane on the runway in Cameroon.
item.description: In West Africa, getting there is way more than half the battle.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
